1 JOURNAL OF MOLECULAR CATALYSIS ELSEVIER Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) 311-324 1H and 51V high-resolution solid state nuclear magnetic resonance studies of supported V205/Ti02 catalysts L.G. Pinaeva*, O.B. Lapina, V.M. Mastikhin, AN. Nosov, B.S Balzhinimaev Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation (Received April 3, 1993; accepted September 30, 1993) Abstract 'H solid state NMR data show the existence of several types of hydroxyl groups on Ti02 surface, depending on the surface impurities. VOC13 selectively interacts with these groups. According to 5' V NMR data, the structure of the surface vanadium complexes, independently of the preparation method, is determined by the type of surface hydroxyls. On clean Ti02 surface at low vanadium concentration two types of surface complexes with vanadium in the distorted tetrahedral environment of oxygen atoms are formed, one of them containing OH groups in the coordination sphere. At high V content associated species, with V in octahedral coordination, are formed. nuclear magnetic resonance studies; solid state; titania; vanadia Key words: ' H-NMR spectroscopy; nuclear magnetic resonance; titania; vanadia; " V-NMR spectroscopy 1. Introduction Supported V205/Ti02 catalysts are widely used in industry for NO, reduction by NH3 [ 1 ] and for selective oxidation of hydrocarbons [ 2 ] . An important information on local environment of vanadium atoms in supported vanadium catalysts was obtained recently by a number of physical methods. The structure of vanadium complexes with two terminal and two bridged oxygen atoms on Ti0z surface has been proposed [ 3 ] . Vanadium atoms in tetrahedral oxygen coordination on anatase were observed with laser Raman spectroscopy [4]. So-called monolayer catalysts obtained by the grafting of VOC13 from gaseous phase tc Ti02 and subsequent hydrolysis are nowadays widely used as the model V201/TiO2 cata- * Corresponding author; fax. (+7-383)2355766. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD10304-5102(93)E0277-N 312 L.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalvsis 88 (1994) 311-324 lysts of partial oxidation of hydrocarbons. According to ESCA measurements, it was proposed that vanadium in these catalysts forms a film of 7-10 A thickness with a V/Ti ratio of about 1 [5] . An excess of vanadium gives VZOS globules. This model is consistent with published data [6]. So, these catalysts can be effectively used for studying surface interactions, resulting in the formation of the active complexes. It is obvious that the structure of the active component of supported catalysts depends on the interaction of vanadium compounds used for catalyst preparation with the surface hydroxyl groups. Infrared spectroscopic studies [ 7-13 ] have revealed the dependence of the type of OH groups and their concentration in anatase on the method of preparation. Recently, IH NMR became an effective method for the studies of surface OH groups [14-16], while SIV NMR is a powerful tool for characterization of the local vanadium environment [ 17-19 ] . In this work we have used both these methods to study the interaction of surface OH groups of anatase with VOC13 as well as for identification of surface vanadium complexes. 2. Experimental Four types of Ti02 obtained by different preparations were used as a support. Sample 1 was prepared by precipitation from TiC14 with ammonia with subsequent washing, drying and calcination at 773 K during 2 h; sample 2 was obtained by pyrolysis of TiC14 in 02; sample 3 was prepared by hydrolysis of titanyl sulfate, sample 4 was obtained by Ti(iBu0)4 hydrolysis with NaZC03. In Table 1 the main characteristics of Ti02 samples (SBET, impurities) are presented. Supported vanadium oxide catalysts were prepared by a grafting technique described previously [20]. Ti02 (anatase) was initially heated in a He flow at 523-773 K for 2 h and then treated by VOC13 in the gaseous phase at 293 K. The excess of Table 1 Properties of anatase samples and their 'H chemical shifts Sample Preparation SBET, Main Chemical shift method m=.g-' impurities 8/ppm ( 0.3 ppm) Ti02_1' precipitation of 55 0.1% Al, 2.9; 6.4 TiCla with NH4 0.1 % Cl Ti0_-26 pyrolysis of 31 3.7% Si, 1.9; 3.2 TiC14 in O_ 0.4%o CI, 0.3% Fe Ti0_-3 hydrolysis of 289 3.9% S, 3.9; 7.6; titanyl sulfate 0.1 % Fe 11.6 Ti024 hydrolysis of 35 2% Na, 2.9; 7.4 Ti(i-BuO, 0.1% Fe with Na2C03 Other impurities are less than 5 X LO-'%. b Sample contained an admixture of rutile. G.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) 311-324 313 VOC13 was removed by heating in a He flow at 673 K. To increase the vanadium coverage, several supporting cycles were used. After hydroxylation of the surface by moist air at 340 K during 2 h with subsequent removal of physically adsorbed water by heating in a He flow up to 410 K, another treatment with VOC13 at 293 K was performed. Depending on the number of supporting cycles and the temperature of the Ti02 pretreatment in He, the vanadium content in the samples varied from 0.85 up to 6.15 wt.%. Then the catalysts were calcined at 723 K during 2 h. Other samples were prepared by the impregnation of these supports with VOS04 solution. They contained about 1 wt.% of V. The 'H NMR MAS spectra were recorded at 300.066 MHz using a Bruker CXP-300 spectrometer. The spectral range was 50 kHz, the pulse duration 5 As and the interval between pulses 5 s. The accumulation number was 103. Before the measurements the samples were placed in a quartz reactor and then dehydrated in a flow of He at different temperatures (from 523 to 773 K) during 1 h. After this procedure they were sealed off in the special glass tubes of 12 mm length and 7 mm outer diameter under the He atmosphere. To diminish the signal from the traces of water on the outer walls of the sample tubes, the latter were heated in the flow of hot air and then placed in the quartz rotor for the 'H NMR MAS measurements. The rotation frequency was about 3 kHz. The chemical shifts (8) were measured with respect to external tetramethylsilane (TMS). The " V NMR spectra were recorded at 105.2 MHz at Bruker MSL-400 spectrometer in a frequency range of 250 kHz, the pulse width was 2 a,s and the interval between pulses was 1 s. The accumulation number ranged from 103 to 3 X 105. The 5' V NMR MAS spectra were measured at 78.86 MHz using a Bruker CXP-300 spectrometer in a frequency range of 150 kHz, the pulse width was 3 us and interval between pulses was from 0.1 to 1 s. The number of scans was from 10; to 104. After the measurement of the 5' V NMR spectra, the samples were treated in a He flow at 723 K during 1 h and sealed in the special quartz ampoules (40 mm length, 10 mm outer diameter), which were then opened in an argon glove box and placed in plastic rotors for MAS measurements, isolated from the atmosphere with paraffin. The rotation frequency was about 4 kHz. The chemical shifts in 5' V NMR spectra were measured with respect to VOC13 as an external reference. 3. Results 3.1. 'H NMR MAS spectra The 'H NMR MAS spectra of anatase samples dehydroxylated in a He flow during 1 h at different temperatures are presented in Fig. 1. They comprise two main peaks each consisting of three overlapping lines with 8=1.5, 2.3, 3.5 ppm (peak A) and 8=5.6; 6.8 and 7.6 ppm (peak B) (Fig. 1, spectrum 1). The ratio of peak intensities depends on the dehydroxylation temperature. As the temperature increases from 523 to 773 K, the total intensity of the signal decreases due to the decrease of the surface area; the peak B decreasing more than peak A (Fig. 1, spectrum 2). Evacuation of the samples at 773 K and P= 10 Torr during 2 h results in complete disappearance of peak B from the spectrum (Fig. 1, spectrum 3) . The total concentration of the surface hydroxyl groups calculated from the L.G. As can be seen from the comparison of Figs. 7A and 7B, the spectra of the samples prepared by two different methods are similar and composed of the same lines. 4. Discussion According to the literature data [ 11,21 ] , the Ti02 surface contains two main types of hydroxyl groups localized on the terminal and bridged oxygen atoms with a formal charge of -1 /3 and + 1 /3 on the protons, respectively. Existence of two types of hydroxyls follows also from IR data [7-13,22]. Two main peaks, A and B, at 8= 2.9 (A) and 6.4 ppm (B ), respectively, (Fig. 1) agree with this model. Downfield peak (B) can be attributed to the positively charged, more acidic hydrogen atoms localized on the bridged oxygens and forming the weak hydrogen bonds with adjacent oxygens. The highfield peak (A) at 8=2.9 ppm can be ascribed to the "more basic" hydrogen atoms bonded to the terminal oxygens. Such an assignment is confirmed additionally by the fact that the peak B is easily removed during dehydroxylation while much higher temperatures are necessary to remove peak A from the spectrum (Fig. 1). A decrease of the concentration of the OH groups during surface dehydroxylation of Ti02 from a value of 9.34 nm-2 (at 300 K) to about 3.2 nm-2 (at 710 K) has also been 320 G.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalvsis 88 (1994) 311-324 observed [ 16] . Unresolved lines in each peak are most probably due to the contribution of OH groups localized on cleavage planes, other than (001). The absence of peak Bin the spectrum of the Ti02-2 sample can be explained by formation of Si-OH groups (8= 1.9 ppm) on the surface of this sample, containing a large amount of silicon impurity. Second, it is necessary to take into account that the given TiO, sample is a mixture of rutile and anatase (see Table 1). Ruble, being the more thermodynamically stable and densely packed Ti02 modification, is expected to locate on the surface [6]. Indeed, two types of hydroxyl groups were observed in the IR spectra of anatase, and only one for rutile [22] . For the TiO,-4 sample the most obvious explanation of the absence of peak B is the replacement of acidic protons with Na ions from Na2C03 used for hydrolysis of the titanium isobutoxide. The line at 8=11.6 ppm in the spectrum of TiO,-3 containing a large quantity of sulfur most probably is due to S-OH groups on the surface of this sample. According to published data [ 9 ] , S-OH groups can exist on Ti02 surface up to an evacuation temperature of 773 K. The interaction of VOC13 with surface OH groups proceeds due to reaction VOC13+nTi-0H-(Ti0) VOCl3_ +nHCI (1<n<3) (1) which results in a decrease of the number of OH groups on the TiO, surface. For different values of n the surface V species bound with Ti02 by one, two or three oxygen atoms can be formed. The 'H NMR data show that VOC13 interacts only with OH groups of B type. No interaction with the more basic OH groups of A type with VOC13 has been observed for any of the four types of Ti02 samples studied. This does not support the supposition on the VOC13 interaction with basic OH groups made previously [6]. The uncertainty in determination of the concentration of surface OH groups from ' H NMR spectra prevents finding the exact value of n in reaction (1). The comparison of the decrease of the intensity of signal from OH groups with the number of V atoms supported on Ti02-l surface shows that supporting of 9.7 X 10'9 g-' V atoms decreases the OH group quantity by (8.4+2) X 10'9 g-'. This means that the averaged stoichiometry of reaction (1) is between 1 and 2, and suggests the formation of different types of surface V species including those containing Cl atoms in their coordination sphere. The formation of several surface V species follows also from 5' V NMR spectra. The lines in the 5' V NMR spectra have been assigned on the basis of previously published reports [ 17-19]. As has been shown there, the anisotropy of chemical shift tensor is the most sensitive parameter for characterization of the local environment of the V nuclei. For the tetrahedral coordination in the most cases 8, =# 82 * 81, 48= 1 81 - 8, 1 < 600 ppm, while for the distorted octahedral coordination the axial anisotropy ( 8, = 82 :* 8,) is typical with anisotropy parameter 48 > 600 ppm. Therefore, lines I and II belong to tetrahedral and lines III and IV, to distorted octahedral V atoms. The line IV can be attributed to crystalline V,O5, since its parameters coincide with those of unsupported V205. At the same time, the lines I, II and III have parameters different from those for any crystalline V compounds and can be ascribed, therefore, to V complexes bound to support. Adsorption of water results in transformation of the tetrahedral coordination of surface complexes (lines I and II) to G.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) 311-324 321 the octahedral one. This follows from the appearance of the axially anisotropic line after HZO adsorption (Fig. 6). Line III can be attributed to octahedral V atoms in the highly disordered surface complexes. The latter follows from the inefficiency of the magic angle spinning, which cannot decrease the width of the inhomogeneously broadened lines. On the contrary, the lines I and II belong to more regular surface species. Additional information about the possible structure of surface complexes could be obtained from 8;co values of surface species. The dependence of 8;co for many chlorinesubstituted compounds of the VOCI (OR)3_, type, where R is an organic or inorganic radical, has been reported [ 23 ] . For VOC12OR compounds 8;_ were about - 300 ppm; for VOCl(OR)2 they were in the range -400 to -510 ppm and for VO(OR)3, in the range -450 to -660 ppm. Using these data, the lines from VOC13 supported on Ti02 before hydration can be identified. For these samples the anisotropic spectra with 81, in the range 0 to - 200 ppm and 81 in the range - 300 to - 400 ppm are observed (8;so varies from - 290 to - 450 ppm). This means that before hydration the supported samples contain two types of complexes bound with the Ti02 surface by one or two bonds: VOC13 OTi and V OCl-(OTi) 2. The hydration would result in the formation of the species of the V O (OH) ,a (OTi) 3 _ type, which are supposed to undergo further rearrangement on thermal treatment. At the moment, the detailed structure of surface complexes is not established. However, the complexes I and II can be attributed to tetrahedral V species with an almost regular structure, probably having OH group in their coordination sphere and bonded with Ti02 surface by one or two bonds. Octahedral complexes III detected at higher V concentration most probably are formed due to association of the complexes I and II, which results in rearrangement of their environment. VZOg is formed at largest V content as it follows from 8,, and 81 values observed for line IV. The impurities, contained on support drastically influence the structure of supported complexes. The presence of sodium (Ti02-4) results in appearance of slightly anisotropic line with 8;so = - 535 ppm, d8 = 150 ppm. These parameters coincide with those of sodium orthovanadate Na3V04, indicating its formation in Ti02 sample containing Na impurities. As has been expected, H20 adsorption does not influence the spectrum of this compound. The interaction of supported V with Na, and not with OH groups in TiOz 4 follows also from the 'H NMR spectra, since the intensity of 'H NMR spectra does not change after supporting of the V complexes. The Si-OH groups in Ti02-2 interact with supporting VOCI3, as it follows from appearance of a new line in the 5'V spectrum with parameters, typical for the V/Si02 system (81 = -500 ppm, 811 _ - 1000 ppm, (Fig. 7A) ). This line transforms to a line with 81 = - 300 ppm, Boo = -1200 ppm upon HZO adsorption. The change of the spectrum on water adsorption shows that this line belongs to surface species, while the 81 and 8,1 values indicate the tetrahedral environment of V nuclei before HZO adsorption. The decrease of intensity of the peak from silanol groups observed in 'H spectra confirms the interaction of V complexes with surface Si-OH groups. Thus, 'H and 5' V data allows one to attribute this line to tetrahedral species bonded with support surface via V-O-Si bond. 2 The presence of 50- anions on the Ti02 surface results in formation of octahedral surface complexes, most probably, having sulfate anions in their coordination sphere. On the surface of the most clean anatase sample (Ti02_ 1) the complexes of the I, II and III type are present. 322 G.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) 311-324 Comparison of the data presented in Fig. 7A and 7B show that for the same support the structure of surface complexes is determined mainly by the structure of support surface. On the same support different preparation methods result in formation of very similar surface structures provided the treatment temperature is high enough (673-773 K). The smaller line width in the spectra of samples prepared from Ti024 and the higher percentage of line II for catalyst prepared from Ti02_1 might be caused by the different treatment temperatures of the supports. (The spectra in Fig. 7A correspond to the samples calcined at 623 K, while the spectra in Fig. 7B correspond to the samples calcinated at 773 K.) This resulted in the formation of Na,V04 for Ti024 and an increase of the concentration of complexes III for Ti02_ 1. Therefore, one can conclude that the main factor that determines the structure and composition of supported vanadium, is the nature of the support surface (i.e., the concentration and the type of OH groups and impurities). The treatment temperature and V concentration of the samples also influences the structure of surface complexes. Recently the 5 `V NMR data on the vanadium oxide species formed on anatase and rutile for ambient atmospheric conditions have been reported [ 24 ] . The authors reported about the marked influence of surface contaminations on the structure of the surface V complexes. This is in agreement with the results obtained in this work. Here we show that formation of the surface species takes place as a result of their interaction with surface OH groups or with contaminations of the support. It is also shown here, that on a clean Ti02 surface at low V content the formation of two tetrahedral sites takes place, while at increased V content octahedral vanadium is also present on the catalyst surface. The tetrahedral coordination is readily transformed to an octahedral one on water adsorption. Thus, the data presented in this paper provide important information on the types of V species on the Ti02 surface. 5. Conclusions From the studies of the V-Ti samples obtained by different ways on different Ti02 supports, the following conclusions can be made: (i) Supported V species selectively interact with surface OH groups. (ii) The types of the surface vanadium complexes depend mainly on the surface chemistry of the support and do not depend significantly on the preparation method, provided the treatment temperature is high enough (600-700 K). On a clean Ti02 surface and on the surface containing S04- ions, VOC13 interacts with the more acidic OH groups. On Ti02 containing silicon or sodium atoms VOC13 interacts with SiOH groups or Na ions, respectively. (iii) Several types of V complexes are formed on Ti02 surface. Vanadium in the surface complexes at low vanadium concentration has a distorted tetrahedral environment from oxygen atoms (complexes I and II). Complex I most probably has OH group in its coordination sphere. The increased vanadium content results in formation of associated complexes with V in octahedral environment (complex III). L.G. Pinaeva et al. /Journal of Molecular Catalysis 88 (1994) 311-324 323 6. Acknowledgement We thank V.Ph. Lyakhova for the preparation of impregnated with vanadyl sulfate Ti02 samples. 7. X244 93E0277N 0304-5102(93)E0277-N 10.1016/0304-5102(93)E0277-N 1H and 51V high-resolution solid state nuclear magnetic resonance studies of supported V2O5/TiO2 catalysts L.G. Pinaeva ∗ O.B. Lapina V.M. Mastikhin A.V. Nosov B.S. Balzhinimaev Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russian Federation * Corresponding author; fax. (+7-383)2355766. 1H solid state NMR data show the existence of several types of hydroxyl groups on TiO2 surface, depending on the surface impurities. VOCl3 selectively interacts with these groups. According to 51V NMR data, the structure of the surface vanadium complexes, independently of the preparation method, is determined by the type of surface hydroxyls. On clean TiO2 surface at low vanadium concentration two types of surface complexes with vanadium in the distorted tetrahedral environment of oxygen atoms are formed, one of them containing OH groups in the coordination sphere. At high V content associated species, with V in octahedral coordination, are formed. nuclear magnetic resonance studies; solid state; titania; vanadia Keywords 1H-NMR spectroscopy nuclear magnetic resonance titania vanadia 51V-NMR spectroscopy References [1] F. coredata.dc:description: 1H solid state NMR data show the existence of several types of hydroxyl groups on TiO2 surface, depending on the surface impurities. VOCl3 selectively interacts with these groups. According to 51V NMR data, the structure of the surface vanadium complexes, independently of the preparation method, is determined by the type of surface hydroxyls. On clean TiO2 surface at low vanadium concentration two types of surface complexes with vanadium in the distorted tetrahedral environment of oxygen atoms are formed, one of them containing OH groups in the coordination sphere. At high V content associated species, with V in octahedral coordination, are formed. nuclear magnetic resonance studies; solid state; titania; vanadia
coredata.dc:title: 1H and 51V high-resolution solid state nuclear magnetic resonance studies of supported V2O5/TiO2 catalysts
